newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ Deputy PM forced to apologise after "scuffle".
newsitem.headline: NZ Deputy PM forced to apologise after "scuffle".

text.p: New Zealand Treasurer and Deputy Prime Minister Winston Peters was forced to apologise to a fellow politician on Thursday after a heated late-night dispute in a corridor of parliament.
Peters, in a radio interview, denied he had abused and assaulted conservative MP John Banks, as Banks alleged.
But he later acknowledged to parliament that they had had a dispute which had "clearly upset" Banks.
"I wish to tender my apology to him unreservedly," Peters told parliament.
The flamboyant Maori politician became number two in the government last December when he steered his New Zealand First party into a coalition with the conservative National Party.

Peters is no stranger to controversy. At one point during protracted coalition talks late last year he missed a negotiating session after being involved in a 2 a.m. altercation with patrons of a Wellington restaurant.

Banks, a National Party MP and former cabinet minister, told Radio New Zealand: "I was assaulted. I was grabbed by the shoulder and close to the scruff of the neck and given one hell of a good shake and push."
Banks complained to the speaker of parliament but said he considered the matter closed after Peters's apology.
Left-wing Alliance party leader Jim Anderton backed Banks' contention that Peters had scuffled with him.
"He grabbed Mr Banks -- and by grabbing I mean he grabbed him quite strongly by the shoulder -- and was either shaking him or physically pushing him across the corridor," Anderton said.
Anderton also said Peters's colleague, Maori Affairs Minister Tau Henare, had physically prevented a Radio New Zealand reporter from tape-recording the incident. Henare apologised to the journalist.
